Fan Zhong must also have known this—why then did he speak in such crude, vulgar terms?

Even the *Kun* [坤] containing *Kan* [坎]—one—still belongs to the true *yuan* [元]. What relevance does this have to *nature* [性]?
What does he take *nature* to be?

This passage follows the errors of the previous section’s lost grasp, and the next section does the same.
The focus here lies in *hidden treasures* [伏藏], while the next section builds upon the last sentence of this one.
Its core organ is the heart—only when the heart is clear can one discern the *machinations* [机].
Fire arises from its root; when disaster strikes, it must be overcome.
Delusion arises within the realm; when it moves, it must collapse.
To know this and refine—this is called the *sage* [圣].

Fan Zhong says:
The first two lines speak of those lacking sincere *precepts* and *meditation*, enslaved by the *spirit-recognition* [识神], casting their bodies into reckless action, losing their true essence, and turning into decay—like fire burning wood.

The middle two lines are a double entendre, also interpretable as the first two lines, but they also point to the *Three Women* [三女] as delusion.
Because there is movement generated within their bodies, and I, in response to their movement, cause their hearts to collapse—at the moment when *heaven* and *human* merge, I unleash my natural *killing intent* [杀机], reversing *post-heaven* into *pre-heaven*.

To know and apply this *arrow-mouth* [矢口] refinement—this is the work of the *sage*.
But this *sage* [圣]—its root is *Kan* [坎], it is *Li* [离].
It speaks of *Kan* and *Li* intersecting, drawing in the *qi* of one to return to the central earth as *king*.

Do not overlook this *sage* [圣]!

One critique says: Fan’s annotations are utterly erroneous and should not be followed.
Not only is his explanation of *knowing* [知] mistaken, but his interpretation of *sage* [圣] also violates the character’s meaning.
The *sage* [圣] is properly composed with *ren* [壬], not *wang* [王].

According to this text, *knowing* [知] is the foundation, *refinement* [修] the application—following the last sentence of the previous section.
Its essence lies in the single *knowing*—only with a foundation can there be application.
How can one refine without knowing?
Refinement is to cultivate the *machinations* of motion and stillness before they manifest.
Only by knowing the *machinations* can one act—thus, the passage’s emphasis is on *knowing*.

One may interpret it straightforwardly without seeking hidden meanings in the characters.
Its essence lies in the dissemination of the *Five Phases*—they must not be allowed to run wild without restraint.
It hangs upon the preceding text, warning: do not forget the meaning of *killing*.

The first two lines speak of *killing intent* hidden within life.
The middle two lines speak of the danger of complacency.
The last two lines speak of the subtlety of knowing how to refine.

Interpreting it directly: if life’s excesses lack restraint, disaster and delusion arise—*sages* warn against them.
The *Way* of governing the world and cultivating oneself is one and the same—this is the text’s true meaning.
Fan Zhong’s explanations are utterly mistaken and twisted. Calling it *sage-work* is a true slander of the *sage*.

As for dissecting *knowing* [知] into *arrow* [矢] and *mouth* [口], there are the *Three Sovereigns’ Jade Precepts* [三皇玉诀] to verify.
Fan Zhong’s interpretation stems from later transmitted oral precepts, unaware that the *Jade Precepts* are grand and majestic—even in broad daylight, the *arrow-mouth* has its use.
It is not merely for loosening the farmer’s belt or adjusting one’s sash—even when facing an enemy, near or far, it makes no difference.
It is said: mountains, rivers, and the earth are all protectors of the *cauldron*; even the dullest living beings are potential medicines.
One must transcend the self’s form and color, still the mind’s deliberations, and retain only *qi*—boundless, without edge or limit.
The six directions and three talents are as insignificant as grains of millet.
My inner radiance shines forth, responding as if summoned—straight as an arrow, revealing *sage sun* and *sage moon*, golden light illuminating, five-colored clouds and mists floating in space, descending swiftly like a gust of wind, unimpeded.
Then the sun and moon merge, suspended in my golden court, gradually nearing and contracting, small as a bean—like a lotus lantern before the Buddha, containing all within its vastness, admitting all in its subtlety.
At this moment, not a single thought arises.

Initially, something emerges from the void, and I sense within myself a myriad of harmonious flavors and sensations—only to be intuited, never to be grasped.
The *Three Sages* [三圣] say this is the peak of *true yuan* [真元], yet still not *true one* [真一].
When *true one* arrives, it enters suddenly and silently, leaving no trace of sound or form—only an awareness of boundless tranquility, steadfast as a mountain, beyond description.

*True yuan* and *true one* move like an arrow to its mark—this is the *arrow*.
It is what the *Buddha* calls *Muni Alaya* [牟尼阿利].

As for *mouth* [口], it is the *Daoist* term for the *mysterious orifice* [玄窍], corresponding to the *wonderful instrument* [奇器] at the end of this text.
A single punch shatters it—this is the *Buddha’s* *other shore*, the *Confucian* *Non-Extreme* [无极].

In the past, when the *Thus-Come-One* taught in that land, five thousand disciples gathered.
Within the *silent treasure-light* [寂宝光], they saw a light straighten and enter the Buddha’s embrace.
The Buddha seemed as if in a drunken stupor, then awoke—hence the tale of the five thousand withdrawing.
It was said the disciples mistakenly thought the Buddha was weary and left.
This serves as proof of the *arrow-mouth*.

chunks.original_text: 若夫经中“故”字，不必从拆字诀会，即以拆字论，亦自有正义。 是言文胜之机，则当反古，此即老子游心于物初之义，奈何证以三峰家作用哉！ 以上数百字，天仙大道尽泄于斯，原不应笔于此节，只因点破矢口。 若不和盘托出，则此知字精义不显。 非以功到此节，始用知字也。 以经义言之，自在天人合发二句中耳，见者审之。 中篇 天生天杀，道之理也。 范氏曰：天生者，常道之顺行也； 天杀者，返道之逆行也。 今以常道自然顺行之身，行逆道自然逆回之奥，故谓天生天杀。 而此专用逆回颠颠倒倒之妙理，方谓成圣登真之大道也。 一得曰：此节盖承上篇天发杀机一节之义理、条理也。 五行无杀机，则四序杂施，而无循环之理矣。 杀中有生，藏生于杀，所以秩然有理，递嬗而不穷也。 天地，万物之盗； 万物，人之盗； 人，万物之盗。 三盗即宜，三才乃安。 范氏曰：万物之荣枯随天地之运转，故天地为万物之盗。 人不能持守，被万物伐贼其真性，故万物为人之盗。 人若能保固不失，掠取万物之真，故人又为万物之盗。 三次之盗，始成一爻，九次之盗，方全乾卦。 个中之先后，不过用人之—口以合其宜，则三爻无非以女而得安全也。 一得曰：旧解“天地，万物之所盗； 万物，人之所盗； 人，万物之所盗”，此解最为直接。 谨按：经义承上，发此篇第一节玄理，而三才喻三田。 用时取宜，无违自然，而各有归，束一如奠，安三才之道。 盗字解见上。 太虚翁谓下篇之奇器，物物自具，故能互相为盗。 究此字之妙义，必须口授。 然不外乎若愚若拙而又若虚，则物得安，大要在一和字。 而范氏谓女而安，异哉！ 所谓既宜且安者。 盖言三田皆宜充裕耳。 第三田之充裕，各有一物，而驯致充裕，自有步骤。 精充则气充，气充则神充，神充精乃足，此则又有一道焉。 此节精义如此。 是则三才奠安之秘旨，其义见于下节。 故曰：食其时，百骸理，动其机，万化安。 范氏曰：故也者，接上文之安字，安十字于口，以返口中之真一。 斯有“故曰”之用食者，食大药也，即“得之者，常如醉”之谓也。 然必因彼之时至。 而彼之时至，必有机现动象。 动象，是机之动象，乃正食彼之时，即人为万物之盗也。 但具此兔髓乌精，人一食之，则周身之骸尽皆通理。 浊阴逐而化清阳者，必素日之退阴符进阳火周天之功。 有万遍之化精气神，是故一食之得安于化。 此万化又岂离女而得安乎。 一得曰：不失其时，而后能食其时； 不弗其机，而后能动其机。 “故曰”二字藏有妙义，亦见三皇玉诀。 其诀惟在返还，而不流复于邃古之初复命之义也。 致一之诀，其惟“曰”字乎。 “曰”也者，个中有一。 万缘故下，意缩身世人我个中，其大无际，一任气机流行，如云如霞，忽复万籁俱息，内外安定，即以意凝之，但觉油然，寂寂无声，三圣谓是真一之来归，乃是曰字玄象，此则所谓无象之象也。 着泥于形，则所得必伪。 能从虚无入手，则曰时，曰机，皆合道矣。

The text within the *scripture* concerning the character **"故"** need not be deciphered through the *dismantling-character* key. Even if analyzed through such a method, its proper meaning remains intact.

This speaks of the principle of *textual mastery*—one must revert to antiquity, embodying the *Laozi’s* teaching of *"wandering in the primal essence of things."* How could one verify this through the *Sanfeng* school’s *actions*?

The preceding hundreds of words exhaust the *Heavenly Immortal’s* Dao entirely. Originally, this should not have been recorded here, but since the *arrow-mouth* was pierced through, if not fully revealed, the profound essence of the character **"知"** would remain obscured. It is not that this knowledge is only applied at this juncture—rather, its meaning is embedded within the two phrases *"self-so of Heaven and man"* from the opening. Let the reader discern this.

---
**Middle Section**

*"Heaven generates, Heaven slays"*—this is the principle of the *Dao*.
Fan Zhong says: *Heaven’s generation* is the natural unfolding of the eternal *Dao*; *Heaven’s slaying* is the inverted return against the *Dao*.
Now, with a body that follows the natural, forward-moving *Dao*, one enters the inverted, counterflowing *mystery*—thus it is called *"Heaven generates, Heaven slays."*
Yet this relies solely on the wondrous, inverted logic of *upside-down reversal*, which alone constitutes the *Great Dao* of attaining sainthood and true transcendence.

*One who grasps this* says: This passage continues the meaning and structure of the earlier *"Heaven’s killing intent"*—if the *Five Phases* lack this killing intent, the four seasons would act chaotically, and the principle of cyclical return would collapse. Within *slaying* lies *generation*; *generation* is concealed within *slaying*—thus order arises, and transformation proceeds endlessly.

*"Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things;
All things are the thieves of man;
Man is the thief of all things."*
When these three thefts are right, the *Three Powers* are at peace.

Fan Zhong says: The flourishing and withering of all things follow the revolutions of Heaven and Earth—thus Heaven and Earth are the thieves of all things. Man, unable to preserve himself, is ravaged by all things, stripping away his true nature—thus all things are the thieves of man. If man can guard himself without loss, seizing the true essence of all things, then man becomes the thief of all things. These three acts of theft complete one *trigram*; nine such thefts fulfill the *Qian* hexagram. The sequence within is merely the use of man’s *mouth* to harmonize what is fitting—thus the three *trigrams* are without fail secured through the *female*.

*One who grasps this* says: The old interpretation—*"Heaven and Earth are what all things steal; all things are what man steals; man is what all things steal"*—is the most direct.

Carefully examining the *scripture’s* intent: It follows the first profound principle of this section, using the *Three Powers* to symbolize the *Three Fields*. Applying them appropriately, without violating nature, each finds its proper place—bound as one, stabilizing the *Dao* of the *Three Powers*.

The meaning of *"thief"* is as explained above. *Taixu Wong* says that the *wonderful instrument* of the next section is inherently possessed by all things, enabling mutual theft. To fully grasp this character’s profundity, oral transmission is required. Yet it ultimately rests in being *as if foolish, as if clumsy, yet as if empty*—thus all things find peace, fundamentally relying on the principle of *harmony*. Yet Fan Zhong speaks of *"securing through the female"*—how strange! This refers to what is both *proper* and *secure*. It means the *Three Fields* must all be abundantly nourished. The abundance of the *third field* depends on a single thing, leading step-by-step to fullness. When *essence* is abundant, *qi* is abundant; when *qi* is abundant, *spirit* is abundant; when *spirit* is abundant, *essence* is fully sufficient—this is yet another *Dao*.

Such is the profound essence of this passage. The secret intent of stabilizing the *Three Powers* is revealed in the following passage. Hence it is said:
*"Eat in season, and the hundred bones harmonize;
Stir the mechanism, and the ten thousand transformations are at peace."*

Fan Zhong says: The *"故"* here follows the *"安"* [peace] of the preceding text, placing the ten characters *"安"* within the *mouth* to restore the *true one* within. Thus arises the phrase *"故曰"*—*"food"* refers to the *Great Elixir*, meaning *"those who obtain it are ever as if drunk."* Yet this must await the opportune *time*. And that *time* must manifest its *mechanism* and *symbols*. The *symbols* are the movements of the *mechanism*—this is the true moment of consumption, when man becomes the thief of all things. But with the possession of *rabbit marrow* and *crow essence*, a single consumption makes the hundred bones throughout the body harmonize. The turbid *yin* is dispelled, transforming into pure *yang*—this requires daily practice of *retreat of the yin符* and *advance of the yang fire* circulating the *Microcosmic Orbit*. With ten thousand transformations of *essence, qi,* and *spirit*, thus one meal suffices to attain peace in transformation. How could this peace be achieved without the *female*?

*One who grasps this* says: Only by not missing the *time* can one eat in season; only by not neglecting the *mechanism* can one stir the *mechanism*. The characters *"故曰"* conceal a profound meaning, also seen in the *Three Sovereigns’ Jade Key*. Its key lies in *returning*, not straying back to the ancient *"initial restoration of command."* The secret of *unification* rests in the character *"曰."*

*"Day"*—within it lies *oneness*.
Following the myriad *affairs*, the mind contracts within the *self, world, people,* and *individual*—its vastness is boundless. One lets *qi* and *mechanism* flow freely, like clouds and mist; suddenly, all sounds cease, and inner and outer are at peace. Then, with the mind focused, one feels a natural, silent stillness—*the Three Saints* call this the *true one’s* return. This is the *mysterious symbol* of *"day,"* the so-called *"formless form."*

To fixate on the *form* leads only to falsity. Only by beginning with *emptiness* can *"day," "time,"* and *"mechanism"* align with the *Dao*.

chunks.original_text: 范氏所述，原属古仙假外众说内功之口诀，而云“岂离女而得安”，则打入邪说矣。 窃按：古字，知字，故字，曰字，虞字，圣字，等等均以识时为要。 然范氏但知泥用一时，不知时时可用。 盖时有活定两说，非仅子午有活定，自子至亥皆有活定。 所谓真一真元，不外一身，而又不泥一身者。 大约于起功之刻，自辨所值景况以定其时，此法最活而最灵。 以一身言之，其时有定活； 以三才六合言之，其时亦有定活。 故其互相感应也，定则应定，活则应活，间不容发，是以时之中有机焉。 时到则机动，机动则化行，是乃自然之妙理，自然之大道。 范氏直坐并观天耳！ 人知其神之神，不知其不神之所以神。 范氏曰：神者，阳也。 神之神者，阳中之阳也，即玄之又玄之谓也。 但此真阳藏于真阴之中，而取此真阳是矢口而得，吕祖所云口对口之神用。 试思以知字中分，岂非矢口两字乎？ 故谓之知其神之神也。 第此之用，不离乎寻常平淡，无一毫矫揉造作之举，似无为而却有为，有为中又却无为。 故谓之知其不神之所以神也。 要知取此阳气，的以奇器，用不神之神法，方其阳气之来，正父母未生前之始气也。 一得曰：此两知字，范氏未得真传，流入邪说，盖不闻虚无之中的有交感之妙义耳。 此节上句乃指物我气神相交于虚无之中所生之真元也。 下句乃言三才真元发扬于上之气，感我之气神上达而应之凝之，则虚无之中合并而生真一也。 谨按经义言，取物我平感合生之物，不过真元，故谓之神之神，不足贵也。 能得彼我气神上感两大，人元降合，虚无而生之物，乃是真一，得而有之，始成圣真之胎，是为至宝。 神与神会，故谓之神之神。 至合中所生一，则虚极矣，不可以神言也，故谓之不神之神也。 语气偏重下句，故有知、不知之别。 日月有数，大小有定，是功生焉，神明出焉。 范氏曰：日阳体属离，阴之小； 月明体而属坎，阳之大。 各有其数，日数须足十六，月数须足五千四十八日。 人以日月之行度为言，非也。 至云前三后三者，乃言甲庚之并，丁壬之合也。 假如成乾之初爻，先用甲前逆排三位癸后之壬并之，次用庚后顺排三位之壬，亦是甲前逆排癸前之壬并之，末又用甲前逆排三位癸后之壬并之。 此正前弦之后后弦前，前三后三之诀也。 如此三并而成乾卦之初爻，如此九并而成乾卦之三爻，方至纯阳地位。 此必日月之数足定，用此成圣之功，使五行攒簇于中宫，而神人生焉、出焉。 是神，人生成，非日月相合为明，未能成就，此正不神之所以神也。 第此之云前三后三，前弦后弦，甲庚丁壬之指，即是火符也。 日月数足，即火符数足。 发现之机，正知其神之神也。 吕祖师所云“遥指天边日月轮”，又云“地下海潮天上月”，崔希范云“天应星，地应潮”，莫不本此解。 实阴符成圣之大道，千古不传之奥义也。 一得曰：日月计庚甲，小大计阴阳，自是易理，范氏之说是也。 谨按此节发明上文“人知”句义，实为千古—鼻心传口诀，而经却以人知言之。 盖黄帝时，修道者多，此种经义，人人知之，故曰：人知其神之神也。 范氏不悟，以此节为不传之秘，是以此节为不神之神，未闻阴符最上上乘功法。

「Master Fan’s account, though ostensibly a recitation of ancient Daoist immortals’ external techniques for internal cultivation, errs when it states *"Shall one not depart from the female to attain peace?"*—this is a deviation into heretical teachings.

In my view: ancient *characters* (古字), *knowing* (知字), *affairs* (故字), *day* (曰字), *Yu* (虞字), *sage* (圣字), and others all hinge upon discerning the *times*. Yet Master Fan only understands fixation upon a single *time*, failing to grasp that *times* may be used flexibly at all moments.

Indeed, *times* have two modes—*fixed* and *active*—not confined solely to the *active* hours of *zi* (子) and *wu* (午). From *zi* (子) to *hai* (亥), each bears its own *fixed* and *active* properties.

The so-called *true one* and *true essence*, though rooted in the *self*, transcend mere fixation upon the *self*. Roughly speaking, at the onset of practice, one must intuitively perceive the prevailing circumstances to determine the *time*—this method is the most *active* and responsive.

When considering the *self* alone, the *time* has *fixed* and *active* distinctions;
When encompassing the *Three Powers* and *Six Harmonies*, the *time* likewise holds *fixed* and *active* nuances.
Thus, their mutual resonance: *fixed* responds to *fixed*, *active* to *active*—without delay, for within *times* lies *mechanism*.

When the *time* arrives, the *mechanism* stirs; when the *mechanism* moves, *transformation* unfolds—this is the wondrous principle of nature, the supreme *Dao*.

Master Fan merely sits upright and gazes at the heavens—his ears attuned to the *times*!
Men know the *divine* of the *divine*, yet fail to recognize the *non-divine* source of its divinity.
Master Fan says: *Divine* is *yang* (神者，阳也).
The *divine* of the *divine* is *yang* within *yang*—the *mysterious* yet deeper *mysterious* (即玄之又玄之谓也).
Yet this *true yang* dwells concealed within *true yin*, and seizing it is done through *direct* utterance—Brü’s *mouth-to-mouth* divine technique.

Consider: within the *knowing* (知) character, is not *direct* (矢) and *utterance* (口) implied?
Thus, it is termed *knowing the divine of the divine*.
This very technique, though seemingly mundane and unadorned, holds no trace of artificiality—it appears as *non-action* yet is *action*, and within *action* lies *non-action*.
Hence, it is called *knowing the non-divine source of divinity*.

To grasp this *yang qi*, one must employ a *strange* vessel (奇器), using the *non-divine* divine method, for when the *yang qi* arises, it is the *initial breath* of the *parents* before their birth.

A critic remarks: these two *knowings* (知), Master Fan failed to receive the true transmission, drifting into heresy. He overlooked the wondrous interplay of *exchange* within *emptiness*—the essence generated by the resonance of *self* and *other* within the void.

The upper line refers to the *true essence* born from the convergence of *self* and *other* in *emptiness*.
The lower line speaks of the *Three Powers’* *true essence* ascending through the *yang qi*, resonating with one’s own *qi* and *divine*—thus, within *emptiness*, the *true one* emerges from their union.

Examining the scripture’s intent: the *essence* drawn from the mutual resonance of *self* and *other* is merely *true essence*—thus, it is termed *the divine of the divine*, yet unworthy of reverence.
If one attains the *great resonance* of *self* and *other’s qi* and *divine*, where the *essence* descends and merges within *emptiness*, generating the *true one*—this is the seed of *sagehood*, the supreme treasure.
*Divine* meets *divine*, hence *the divine of the divine*.
Within the ultimate union, the *one* born is *emptiness* at its zenith—beyond mere *divinity*, thus termed *the non-divine source of divinity*.
The emphasis shifts downward, hence the distinction between *knowing* and *not knowing*.

The sun and moon follow their set cycles, their *fixed* and *active* properties yielding practice and enlightenment.
Master Fan says: the sun’s *yang* nature belongs to *li* (离), the lesser *yin*;
The moon’s *bright* nature aligns with *kan* (坎), the greater *yang*.
Each has its own count: the sun requires sixteen, the moon five thousand four hundred eighty.
Men mistakenly speak of the sun and moon’s degrees—this is incorrect.
The *"three before, three after"* refers to the pairing of *jia* (甲) and *geng* (庚), the union of *ding* (丁) and *ren* (壬).

For instance, in the *initial line* of the *Qian* (乾) hexagram:
First, employ *jia*’s inverse sequence paired with *wu* (午) from *gui* (癸) to *ren* (壬);
Next, use *geng*’s forward sequence paired with *wu* (午) from *gui* (癸) to *ren* (壬)—this is *jia*’s inverse sequence paired with *wu* (午) from *gui* (癸) to *ren* (壬);
Lastly, again employ *jia*’s inverse sequence paired with *wu* (午) from *gui* (癸) to *ren* (壬).
This is the *mechanism* of *"three before, three after"*—the *ascending* and *descending* phases.

Thus, three such pairings complete the *Qian* (乾) hexagram’s *initial line*,
And nine such pairings fulfill the *Qian* (乾) hexagram’s *third line*—
Only then does one reach the *pure yang* state.

This requires the sun and moon’s *times* to be *fixed* and *active* in measure—
To perfect the *sage’s* practice, gathering the *Five Phases* within the *central palace*,
Wherefrom *divine beings* and *men* arise, emerge.
This is the *divine* and *men*’s fulfillment—
Not through the sun and moon’s union yielding *brightness*, but by the *non-divine* source of divinity.

The *"three before, three after"* and *"ascending, descending"* references to *jia-geng-ding-ren* (甲庚丁壬) are indeed the *fire talismans*.
When the sun and moon’s counts are fulfilled, the *fire talisman’s* count is complete.
The moment of revelation is the very *knowing* of the *non-divine* source of divinity.

As Brü’s master taught: *"Pointing afar at the celestial sun and moon"* and *"below the earth’s tides, above the moon’s glow"*—
And as Cui Xi-Fan said: *"Heaven responds to stars, earth to tides"*—
All derive from this understanding.
This is the *Yin Symbol’s* supreme *Dao*, the untransmitted mystery of ages.

A critic concedes: counting *geng-jia* (庚甲) for the sun and moon, and *yin-yang* (阴阳) for *great* and *small*—
This is indeed the *principle* of the *Yijing*.
Master Fan’s words are correct.

Yet, this passage elucidates the *"men know"* (人知) line’s meaning—
A secret transmitted through the *nose’s center*, passed down orally for millennia,
Yet the scripture speaks of it as *"men know"* (人知).
During the Yellow Emperor’s era, practitioners of the *Dao* were many—
This teaching was universal, hence it is said: *"Men know the divine of the divine."*
Master Fan fails to comprehend, deeming this an untransmitted secret—
Thus, he calls it *"the non-divine source of divinity,"*
Unaware that the *Yin Symbol’s* highest *highest* cultivation lies beyond his grasp.»

So it is that the *Three Talents* (三才) decay, yet I endure eternally.

This is the *playful cultivation* (玄修) of the *Three Sovereigns* (三皇), still not the *secret* (秘) known by the Yellow Emperor’s era. As for *stealing the mechanism* (盗机), none under Heaven can see it, none can know it. The *noble* (君子) who attains it will preserve their life, while the *petty* (小人) who attains it will risk their vitality. Master Fan says: *"Stealing"* (盗) is the *Dao/Way* (道). The *saintly virtue/power* (圣功) manifests through observing its *mechanism* (机), then applying it to *steal* (盗) the *lifespans* (夭) of both the *noble* (君子) and the *petty* (小人).

The *true yang* (真阳) of the *seven* (一七) cannot be seen by the eyes, but the *true yang* (真阳) of the *lower seven* (下一七) can only be obtained through the *spear-mouth* (矢口). The *noble* (君子) knows that the *true yang* (真阳) of both the *noble* (君子) and the *petty* (小人) must be returned through the *Ten-character Great Mouth* (十字大口) and *Small Mouth* (小口) methods, to preserve their life and ensure eternal existence. The *petty* (小人) cannot self-restraint, relying on their talents while neglecting cultivation, they fall into *evil paths* (邪道), losing their life without realizing it—hence the phrase *"lightly risking their vitality"* (轻命). This illustrates the *auspiciousness and inauspiciousness* (吉凶) of *right and wrong* (邪正).

A scholar remarks: the *"its"* (其) in this section refers to the *Dao/Way* (道) mentioned in the previous section. *"Stealing"* (盗) means *secretly taking and concealing* (密取而藏). *"Mechanism"* (机) is the *interaction of self and other* (彼我所发之机). If not concealed, it will dissipate—thus, the value lies in knowing how to *steal* (盗). None can see or know it, hence it is called *"stealing"* (盗). Yet, it is crucial to *preserve the universal mind* (普心), preventing *one-sided dominance* (偏胜). This contains the dual meaning of *"taking and giving"* (取与).

To know this is to be a *noble* (君子); to be unaware is to be a *petty* (小人). Here lies the *Heavenly Mandate* (天命). Those who *observe Heaven and embody Heaven* (观天执天) cannot afford to neglect the *mechanism of stealing* (盗机). Aligning with Heaven preserves the body, while *pursuing private gains* (挟私) through stealing leads to *lightly risking vitality* (轻命). What does *"attaining"* (得) mean? It is the *Dao/Way of taking and giving* (取与之道).

This section belongs to the *initial stages of cultivation* (小试之道), hence the warning. Master Fan fails to grasp this, so his interpretations fall into the category of *lightly risking vitality* (轻命), and cannot be followed.

“倍”字拆看，乃阴阳门地天作用，须连十字合参。
“万”字拆看，乃“艹禺”两字，艹属坤气，禺属阴类，此就范氏解法言之。
按理而论，用倍字作用，较胜范氏所宗。」

The *deaf* (聋者) excel in *vision* (善视), and the *blind* (瞽者) excel in *hearing* (善听).
To *sever all profit from a single source* (绝利一源), one must employ the *Master* (师) tenfold (十倍).
To *return three times through day and night* (三返昼夜), one must employ the *Master* (师) ten thousand-fold (万倍).

Master Fan says: this refers to the moment in cultivation (功) when one encounters the *beautiful mouth* (美口), requiring the *vision* (视) of the *deaf* (聋者) and the *hearing* (听) of the *blind* (瞽者).
The two *excellences* (善) illustrate the meaning of *single-mindedness* (专), and also imply *using the mouth while the mind remains without attachment* (用口而心无口).
Understand that in cultivation, *stealing* (盗) must be employed, and without the *mouth* (口), one cannot *take* (取).
The *true one* (真一) of the *silken threads* (丝) and *colors* (色) lies at the *source* (源头), and the *use of the mouth as a single source* (口一源) is most critical.
First, one must apply the *ears and eyes* (耳目) to the *mechanism* (机); only after attaining the *mechanism* (机) does one employ their *mouth* (口), and once the *mouth* (口) is used, it is through the *Ten-character* (十字) method.
If one truly employs the *Ten-character* (十字) and *returns three times to the root source* (三返根源), it is like the *precise and perilous* (危厉) tactics of a *military strategist* (兵师).
This is akin to *planting lotuses in flames* (火里栽莲), truly yielding *ten thousand-fold gains* (万倍之获).
It is through *uninterruptedly preserving ears, eyes, and mouth* (全耳目口宵旦不辍) that one achieves the *advantage of stealing the mechanism* (盗机之利), thus giving rise to the *application of the mind’s mechanism* (机心) in the following passage.
The *character "bai"* (倍) holds another profound meaning, which I dare not commit to writing—please do not overlook it.

A scholar remarks: the *first two sections* (上中两篇) discuss the *correctness of their principles* (义理之当), yet they also hint at their *advantages and disadvantages* (利弊).
This *section* (下篇) speaks of the *method* (功法), while the *principles* (义理) are encountered within it.
From this, one must *discriminately adopt or abandon* (去取) and *assess gains or losses* (损益) accordingly—then the method is complete.
To *comprehend and embody* (统而体之) it lies in *single-mindedness* (专一), in *ultimate stillness and supreme emptiness* (至静极虚), where there is no *self or other* (人我), and one *fully trusts in nature* (一任自然), perceiving *presence and absence* (有有无无) solely through *qi and mechanism* (气机).
Here, there is *constant quietude* (常寂寂); if one *forgets this quietude* (忘其寂), then one can *operate* (运) to reach *constant response and constant stillness* (常应常静).
This passage’s first two lines elucidate the meaning of *single-mindedness* (专), and the third line, that of *oneness* (一).
The *eyes* (目) profit from *vision* (视), the *ears* (耳) from *hearing* (听); the *deaf* (聋) and *blind* (瞽) can *sever their distractions* (绝其歧), thus *unifying the source* (源一).
The fourth line gathers the meaning of *benefit* (益), verified here.
The phrase *"return three times"* (三返), carries the meaning of *constancy* (恒).
*Master* (师) means *the multitude* (众); in the *Yijing’s* *Master Hexagram* (师卦), it speaks of *accumulating the multitude* (畜众), which is precisely the *Dao/Way* (道) of *returning to benevolence* (归仁) and *encountering the source* (逢源) amid a crowd.
*Return three times through day and night* (三返昼夜) refers to *thirty-six hours* (三十六时).
Thirty-six is the *extreme of yin numbers* (阴数之极).
If one can be *single-minded and constant* (专而恒), then *all yin transforms into yang* (阴尽化阳), and the *thirty-six palaces* (三十六宫) are all *spring* (春).
*Tenfold* (十倍) and *ten thousand-fold* (万倍) are *approximate terms* (约词).
They mean that *single-mindedness* (专一) allows one to *employ the multitude* (用众), and *constancy* (恒) further enables *tenfold or ten thousand-fold application* (倍用).
The *character "bai"* (倍), when deconstructed, reveals the *yin-yang* (阴阳) *gateway and foundation* (门地) of *Heaven’s operation* (天作用), which must be *connected with the Ten-character* (十字) for full understanding.
The *character "wan"* (万), when deconstructed, reveals the *two characters "cao-yu"* (艹禺): "cao"* (艹) belongs to *Kun-qi* (坤气), and *"yu"* (禺) belongs to the *yin category* (阴类). This is in accordance with Master Fan’s method of interpretation.
By *reasoning* (按理), the *application of "bai"* (倍) surpasses what Master Fan adheres to.

chunks.original_text: 然按正义只言道不孤修，学者能循是经正宗，纵在一室孤修而虚空感至真一、真元，采不胜采，竟有十倍、万倍之获。 是经正义不在拆字也。 谨按此节意在立命，而辞旨注在性边，盖以命圆在性耳！ 学者审之，则知所事矣。 心生于物，死于物，机在目。 范民曰：心为物机所牵，是为物之用，虽心生而自促其死也。 心不为物机所牵，将物为心所用，是心死而自得其生也。 此正不死不生，不生不死之谓也。 然生死之途，用目观机而定，正为办道之津梁。 心假目之用，必学如死人之不动，为最要之上看也。 一得曰：引于物而情动，为生于物。 役于物而神耗，耗则弊，为死于物。 心因物而生死，实则已无生死。 凡生于物之时，而能觉照，则无死机矣。 其机惟目见之。 目，乃天目，位在两眉之间，非两目也，是为真一之所凭临者。 用目瞩机，机绪万端，变幻莫测，目能见端识绪，见绪识端，而机莫遁矣。 目之用大矣哉！ 故曰：“心生于物，死于物”。 又曰：“机在目也”。 此示人须凭真一为宰耳。 知用与否，乃在一心，故贵心明。 心明乃能见性，故学以明心地为澈始澈终要着。 按此目字，即上篇将观字之主脑。 圣人所以用目者，盖以明心，意在言外。 静揣上下经文，厥旨自见。 天下之无恩而大恩生，迅雷烈风莫不蠢然。 至乐性余，至静性廉。 天下之至私，用之至公。 范氏曰：二人之不间，不作尘情之拘扰，全无常道顺生之为，是为无恩。 俟其时，至机现，是大药生矣。 当此之时，须分别壬癸，使庚甲相合。 吞入腹中，返成乾体，而得长生，岂非大恩乎。 然，金木之并，不过烈风之顷，再加当头一震，跃然蠢动，顿脱狂迷，天真吐露矣。 全赖神此—击。 故吕祖云“霹雳声中自得根”之语，堪为证据。 但生来一厶之小土击出兑中一丝之白金，食之虽小而堪充六合。 生来一厶之小土，原来清静，承受一滴之青阳，凝然不争。 其廉小，但二人一厶土之功用固属不可见之私为。 而我太空一震，得返成真，却显现人我一厶土中为用，故又谓之公。 是此四至字莫非归中守中之旨也。 一得曰：至乐，性之动也也。 余者，溢于外也。 至静，性之定也。 廉者，约于内也。 雷雨之动满盈，故有充溢之应。 迅雷烈风必变，故戒侈放之愆。 “莫不蠢动”，是用之公。 惟修道者，感风雷而受益，是独得天恩之私也。 此节玄理，如此。 声音之感，莫大于风雷，此节是承上“善听”之义，上节承上“善视”之义。 二节言视听之灵。 应机不泊，而后有下节制禽之作用也。 范氏之说，亦可节取，然只可会其意，而行之于虚寂之中，一或泥于迹，便非大道。 禽之制在炁。 范氏曰：此专言隹，正明天人合发之妙用。 是用隹而不用形之作用，如鹤以声交也。 其用隹之旨，非身中之隹。 若不以功力制之，隹亦不来，而我之任督不通，升降路塞，纵得亦失，无招摄伏藏之所也。 盖隹即阳人得阳则生，失阳则死人，为仙鬼之各半。 行此功者，正去阴益阳之为也。 但神既迷离于纷华，气又亏失于爱欲，非此相机以制，相感以隹之妙，何能返还于本原也。 一得曰：范氏此节，不愧玄解二字，实为无有遗憾。 惜上篇观字不从洪武正韵拆看，讹从贴体，乃有用夫二口于佳花之上云云。

「Yet according to the *orthodox interpretation* (正义), it merely states that the *Dao/Way* (道) is not cultivated in isolation. Scholars who follow this scripture’s *true essence* (正宗) will find that even in solitary practice within a single chamber, if one attains the *True One* (至真一) and *True Essence* (真元) of the *void* (虚空), the harvest would be *tenfold* (十倍) or *ten thousand-fold* (万倍) beyond measure.

This scripture’s *orthodox interpretation* (正义) does not lie in deconstructing characters. The intent of this passage is to establish *command* (命), while its meaning focuses on the *nature* (性). Indeed, *command* (命) is rooted in *nature* (性)! Scholars who examine it carefully will understand what they must pursue.

*The heart-mind* (心) arises from things and perishes from things; its trigger lies in the eyes. Master Fan says: When the *heart-mind* (心) is drawn by the *mechanism* (机) of things, this is the *operation of things* (物之用), though the *heart-mind* (心) may arise, it is itself hastening its own demise.

When the *heart-mind* (心) is not drawn by the *mechanism* (机) of things, it instead makes things serve its own *operation* (用), which is the *heart-mind* (心) attaining its own life through its own demise. This is the meaning of *neither death nor life, nor life nor death* (不死不生，不生不死).

However, the path of life and death is determined by using the eyes to observe the *mechanism* (机), serving as the *bridge for Dao/Way practice* (办道之津梁). The *heart-mind* (心) relies on the eyes’ *operation* (用), and must learn to remain as *immovable as the dead* (不动), which is the most crucial *observation* (上看).

*A True Attainment* (一得) says: To be drawn by things and have one’s *emotions* (情) move is to *arise from things* (生于物). To be enslaved by things and have one’s *spirit* (神) exhausted—exhaustion leading to decay—is to *perish from things* (死于物). Though the *heart-mind* (心) experiences life and death through things, in truth, it has already transcended life and death.

Whenever one *arises from things* (生于物), if one can *awaken and illuminate* (觉照), then the *mechanism of death* (死机) will vanish. The *mechanism* (机) is discerned solely through the eyes.

The eyes are the *Heavenly Eyes* (天目), located between the two brows—not the physical eyes—and serve as the *True One* (真一)’s foundation. By using the eyes to *gaze upon the mechanism* (瞩机), myriad threads of the *mechanism* (绪) emerge, shifting and unpredictable. Yet if the eyes can perceive the threads and grasp the *mechanism* (绪), the *mechanism* (机) cannot escape detection. The eyes’ *operation* (用) is indeed vast!

Thus it is said: *“The heart-mind arises from things and perishes from things”* (心生于物，死于物). And again: *“Its trigger lies in the eyes”* (机在目). This teaches that one must rely on the *True One* (至真一) for governance. Whether one employs its *operation* (用) depends on the *heart-mind* (心), hence the value of *heart-mind clarity* (心明). *Heart-mind clarity* (心明) is the ability to perceive *nature* (性), so the practice must focus on *heart-mind clarity* (明心) as both its beginning and end.

Examining the *character "mu"* (目), it aligns with the *core principle* (主脑) of the *observation* (观) in the previous section. The *Sages* (圣人) employ the eyes precisely to illuminate the *heart-mind* (心), though their intent lies beyond the words.

Reflecting on the *upper and lower scriptures* (上下经文) in stillness, their profound meaning becomes evident. Beneath the *Dao/Way*’s apparent lack of *en* (恩), the greatest *en* (恩) arises. Even the swiftest thunder and fiercest wind cannot fail to stir the *innate response* (蠢然).

The *supreme joy* (至乐) is the *nature*’s overflow, the *supreme stillness* (至静) is the *nature*’s restraint. The *Dao/Way*’s ultimate *selflessness* (至私) manifests as ultimate *public benefit* (至公). Master Fan explains: The *non-separation of two* (二人之不间) refers to those who do not indulge in the *entanglements of mundane emotions* (尘情之拘扰), maintaining the *natural flow of the constant Dao/Way* (常道顺生). This is the state of *lacking en* (无恩).

When the time arrives and the *supreme mechanism* (至机) appears, the *great medicine* (大药) is born. At this moment, one must distinguish *ren-gui* (壬癸) to harmonize *geng-jia* (庚甲). Swallowing this into the *abdomen* (腹中), it transforms back into the *primordial body* (乾体), granting *long life* (长生)—is this not the greatest *en* (恩)?

Yet the *confluence of metal and wood* (金木之并) lasts only as long as the *fierce wind* (烈风), and an additional *strike at the crown* (当头一震) causes a sudden awakening—*innate response* (蠢动)—and one breaks free from *madness and delusion* (狂迷), revealing the *Heavenly True Self* (天真吐露). This is entirely due to the *divine impact* (神此—击).

Thus, Master Lü said, *“Within the thunderous clap, the root is naturally attained”* (霹雳声中自得根), which serves as evidence.

Even a *single clod of earth* (一厶之小土) struck from the *Fu position* (兑中) produces a *thread of white gold* (一丝之白金). Though small, it can nourish the *Six Harmonies* (六合). A *single clod of earth* (一厶之小土) is inherently *pure and tranquil* (清静), receiving a *drop of celestial yang* (一滴之青阳) without struggle or contention. Though its *restraint* (廉) is slight, the *function and operation* (功用) of the *two persons’ single clod of earth* (二人一厶土) belong to the *invisible private* (不可见之私). Yet when *Great Void* (太空) strikes with a single *resonance* (震), it returns to the *True* (真), revealing the *operation* (用) within the *single clod of earth* (一厶土) of *self and others* (人我), hence also called *public* (公). Thus, these *four “zhi” terms* (四至字) all point to the essence of *central harmony and preservation* (归中守中).

*A True Attainment* (一得) says: *Supreme joy* (至乐) is the *nature*’s movement (动), *overflow* (余) is its external excess. *Supreme stillness* (至静) is the *nature*’s fixation (定), *restraint* (廉) is its internal constraint. The *dynamic response* (动) of thunder and rain is full and abundant, hence the *overflowing effect* (充溢之应). Swift thunder and fierce winds must transform, so one must guard against *excess and dissipation* (侈放之愆). *“Even the swiftest thunder and fiercest wind cannot fail to stir”* (莫不蠢动) is the *public operation* (用之公). Only those cultivating the *Dao/Way* (修道者) benefit from the wind and thunder, uniquely receiving *Heaven’s great en* (天恩) as *private* (私). The profound *Dao/Way*’s meaning here is such.

No sensation surpasses the impact of *wind and thunder* (风雷), so this passage aligns with the *orthodox interpretation* (正义) of *“good hearing”* (善听) from above. The previous passage corresponds to *“good vision”* (善视). Both passages emphasize the *spiritual acuity* (视听之灵) of the eyes and ears.

Only when one *responds to the mechanism without stagnation* (应机不泊) does the following passage on *subduing the beast* (制禽) unfold in its *operation* (用). Master Fan’s teachings can be selectively applied, but one must grasp their intent and practice within the *void and stillness* (虚寂). If one becomes mired in the *traces* (迹), it will no longer be the *Great Dao/Way* (大道).

The *subduing of the beast* (制禽) lies in *qi* (炁). Master Fan says: This passage specifically discusses *zui* (隹), illustrating the *marvelous operation* (妙用) of *Heaven and humanity* (天人) in unison. Its *operation* (用) is through *zui* (隹), not the *form* (形). This is akin to the *crane’s communication through sound* (鹤以声交).

The intent of *using zui* (用隹) is not the *zui within the body* (身中之隹). If one does not employ *cultivation strength* (功力) to control it, *zui* (隹) will not manifest. Without *zui* (隹), the *task and governing vessels* (任督) remain blocked, and the *paths of ascent and descent* (升降路) are obstructed. Even if attained, it will be lost, lacking the means for *summoning, subduing, concealing, and storing* (招摄伏藏).

Indeed, *zui* (隹) is the *yang essence in humans* (阳人), gaining *yang* (阳) brings life, losing *yang* (阳) brings death. It is the *halfway point between immortals and ghosts* (仙鬼之各半). Practitioners of this *operation* (功) must *eliminate yin and augment yang* (去阴益阳).

Yet when the *spirit* (神) is lost in the *flurry of worldly affairs* (纷华), and *qi* (气) is depleted by *attachment and desire* (爱欲), without this *mechanism of mutual response and control* (相机以制，相感以隹), how could one return to the *original foundation* (本原)?

*A True Attainment* (一得) says: Master Fan’s exposition here is worthy of the terms *profound and insightful* (玄解), with no flaw in its reasoning. It is regrettable that the *character "guan"* (观) in the previous section was not deconstructed according to the *Hongwu Zhenyun* (洪武正韵) but instead followed the *erroneous method of "tie-ti"* (贴体), leading to the misguided notion of *“applying the two mouths to the fine flower”* (用夫二口于佳花之上).*」

「If one deconstructs the *character "zhuì"* (隹) as intended, then the meaning of this passage and sentence becomes clear. For *zhuì* is a swift and sensitive bird—when its mechanism is touched, it immediately acts. Hence, the *character "jiàn"* (见) is placed on its right.

This is how one discerns the nature of *zhuì*: by using *qi* (炁) to control it, so that *zhuì* does not perceive it. When the time comes and the mechanism is at hand, the two *qi* (炁) having met, *zhuì* will naturally cling and merge, forgetting its own thrust. Such is the meaning of the *character "guān"* (观), and its application lies in the *qi* (炁).

What *qi* (炁) is this? It is the *qi* of the *Kun* (坤) element. For this bird is the *li* (离) crow, embodying the true essence of the *jīng* (精) and *liúzhū* (流珠). Its nature is swift and sensitive. Does it not say in *Cántóng Bù* (参同不云乎): *“The Great Yang flows the pearl, ever desiring to abandon [the vessel], yet ultimately attains the essence, transforming to sustain each other”*? What is this *jīnhuá* (金华)? It is the *qi* of the *Kun* element.

When the time arrives, the *kǎn* (坎) marrow ascends—this is the *tùsuǐ* (兔髓), and when *kǎn* and *lí* unite, it condenses into white fluid, solidifying until it is firm. When condensed, it does not disperse—this is the *control* (制). Such is its effect, a marvel of nature’s operation. The key to its attainment lies in its pristine, undisturbed state.

*The Classic of Changes* (易) states: *“Exalted is the *Kun* element, from which all things derive their life, thus following and conforming to Heaven.”* This is the essence of this passage, though Master Fan has not yet grasped it. Life is the root of death; death is the root of life. Grace arises from harm; harm arises from grace.

Master Fan says: *“Death is the Way’s constant operation; life is the Way’s inverted function.”* When the Way’s constant operation generates life, it means the *spirit* (神) is lost in emotional desires, and thus the *essence* (精), *qi* (气), and *spirit* (神) are depleted, inevitably leading to death. Hence, life is considered the root of death. When the Way’s inverted function generates the body, it means the *spirit* (心) is extinguished by emotional desires, so the *essence* (精), *qi* (气), and *spirit* (神) remain intact, inevitably leading to life. Hence, death is said to be the root of life. This aligns with *Zhìyáng’s* (紫阳) teaching: *“Only treat the gate of death as the gate of life; never mistake the door of life for the door of death.”*

In summary, by applying the Way’s inverted *mechanism of mutual response and control* (伏藏), one’s body not yet dead, must first learn the Way of death, only then can one achieve full life. Just as dragons and serpents rise from land due to the *tēng* (腾) of nurtured *qi* and blood; thunder and lightning strike, winds blow, because of the timing of the *Dāntái* (丹台) and *yuèyìn* (月印). Hence, grace arises from harm. When *jiānxié* (奸邪) is hidden within the realm, it marks the moment of inevitable collapse into theft and plunder; when leaves flourish and flowers bloom, it reveals the completion of *yin* depletion and *yang* return. Hence, harm arises from grace.

The following two sentences speak to the timing of the *fire candidate* (火候). Its relation to the *mechanism of mutual response and control* (相负) of *xíng* (刑) and *dé* (德) should be examined together. *A True Attainment* (一得) says: *“The five phases mutually generate life and death, hence grace and harm also rely on and conceal each other. This passage logically follows the text, and its meaning is sufficient. It serves as an introduction to the following section, continuing the significance of the *character 'zhì'* (制). The key lies in discerning *qi* mechanisms, preventing them from becoming excessive or one-sided, and responding to them with counter-control. Then success is achieved—harm is transformed into grace, death into life.”*

The next passage reveals the method for practical application. The *fire candidate* (火候) depends on timing, which is the means to verify the *qi* mechanisms’ sequence and reliance. The *adoption and extraction* (采取) lies in substances, which is the means to balance the excesses and deficiencies of *yin* and *yang* within one’s body. Its application is profound; its mechanism is subtle. Yet it does not exceed what this passage has spoken.

The purpose of this passage is to say that only those who exhaust their nature can achieve the Way’s full potential. From this passage onward, it focuses purely on the principles of life and death, yet within it still lies the nature that governs them. Master Fan’s explanation here also has merits worth adopting.

The unenlightened say: *“The patterns and principles of Heaven and Earth are sacred.”* I say: *“The patterns and principles of time and matter are profound.”* Master Fan says: *“Yú* (禺) is the mother monkey. The *Yú* of Heaven and Earth, with its abundant *qi*, naturally reveals the sacred patterns and principles, as the sign of *kǎn* and *lí* uniting, entering the center to form soil. This is the meaning of observing Heaven and Earth—it is not the mundane study of celestial omens and terrestrial features, but the profound range of the *numbers of the sun and moon* (日月有数), the *fixed order of great and small* (小大有定), and the *harmonious manifestation of Heaven and man* (天人合发). It is the Way of seizing the *spirit’s* mechanism and altering one’s fate, entirely contained here. Hence, the patterns and principles of Heaven and Earth are called sacred, as the unenlightened know them.”*

I say: *“The numbers of the sun and moon, the fixed order of great and small, and the timing of mechanisms—by using the unmanifested *spirit* (不神之神) to compel it to steal these mechanisms, and thus reveal the sacred patterns and principles, the principles of time and matter harmonize the sacred and the profound. One can further, in the midst of chaotic material inducements, command the sacred patterns and principles of Heaven and Earth to operate silently within oneself, and thus balance the *qi* mechanisms through the profound principles of matter. This timing’s patterns and principles are what we encounter from morning to evening, in the most familiar and ordinary of places—this is the crucial key for transforming the sacred and the mundane.”*

People cannot err in this; please examine it carefully.

*A True Attainment* (一得) says: *“What is manifest externally is the *patterns* (文); what is internal and harmonious is the *principles* (理). Both the sacred and the profound understand and penetrate these. Though they may know the celestial patterns of stars and constellations, and the terrestrial principles of mountains and rivers, even if they understand the omens and symbols, they are merely traces of Heaven and Earth, not the Way of Heaven and Earth itself. ‘Time’ encompasses both Heaven and man. Heaven has fixed times, the human body has its own rhythms—these shifts and manifestations all have distinct patterns and orderly principles, which must not be misapplied when practicing. The use of time is vast indeed! ‘Matter’ refers to what is opposite to me, meaning humanity. The traces and symbols seen below coalesce into human patterns. The *spirit* (神) and *qi* (气) that manifest above each have their own order, and their responses and unions do not disrupt one another. The use of matter is broad indeed! Those who dedicate themselves to the Way all seek it from Heaven, Earth, time, and matter. Yet what people overlook is that the great Way lies within time and matter themselves. The flow of *qi* mechanisms through Heaven and Earth, when calculated and verified, is what the eye perceives—”*」

chunks.original_text: 消息之感通于时物者，默体而符，目之所不见也，此阴符之旨也。 直解之理如此。 按：此节是示两家各正性命之大旨，具有双管齐下妙理。 拆愚言愚者，指女人之心而言，《左传》：“女，阳物也，其性专静”。 当以用心入手，故宜以自身天地文理融会贯通时，感合虚空所生之真一，以为圣胎。 我则以无心为用者，故但于时物文理充足，机现时，极虚极寂，机自来合，以真意包之，乃成圣胎。 盖禺本无心，其机易感； 我本中实，非虚莫纳。 其理如此。 阴符正旨，禺我各处一方，各有气机外透而气机各不离其体，乃有若现勿现之玄，三才一元充满六合，彼我克修，各自达于虚无之境，三才三宝，以无为舍者。 无与无遇，相合无分。 而此中各具阴阳，空中媾结，变化出焉。 若欲形容其妙，罄南山之竹不能尽之。 虚无更加寂静，则万化之相交心畅，而所生必充。 及至不失其时，虚受其物，则互有所得，彼我个中各各积玉成山，铺金成地。 此正上篇天发杀机一节之作用而基筑于此节者。 圣人统男女而普度之，故又有下节功法所以别开生面也。 其诀至玄，而功用却极平近。 然，古今人阅是经而鲜克领悟者，以无口授故耳。 一得窃体师意，已将玄旨和盘托出，见者幸共勉旃。 人以愚虞圣，我以不愚虞圣。 人以奇期圣，我以不奇期圣。 沉入水火，自取灭亡。 范氏曰：愚者，不识不知情懵懵然之谓。 是指其人要如愚之说也。 虞者，恐人知觉我之所为，又以口喻我中宫之说也。 圣者，不类常道，故云以愚虞圣。 我明宇宙在手，万化生身，坎离之交，金木之并，圣功之生，神明之出自然无为之道，故云不愚虞圣。 此“愚虞圣”三字之秘旨也。 一得曰：范氏解经悖谬之由总缘认经为男子而设，继泥于拆字，不得口传，一凭私智，且更认元为一，故费尽心思，适堕旁门。 不如据文直解，厥义自明。 虞，度也。 圣，通明也。 愚，谓定静如愚，实不愚也。 奇，谓作用神异。 圣道自然，不在奇也。 矫强作用，则自取灭亡矣。 此节语意，正以起下文“自然”二字。 看去似浅近，而玄旨甚深。 盖黄帝之时，言道不言丹。 至后世有种种说法，然不过身心两字尽之。 按此节，是从上节透入，别开生面，乃涵万于一之妙用，彼我并成之大道。 然，非造作而出。 故此下节点出“自然”二字。 言以静字为入手，而以至静至虚得用奇器为真功，造至粉碎虚空为了当。 经尚秘之，未尽泄也。 此节玄义，须从吕祖印传口诀以解之。 若曰上节言入手之则，时物文理息息静参，则日月小大之中有神明之用。 此节功法并将日月小大、时物文理等等作用，一脚踢翻。 是乃涵三为一，戴高履厚，并作一身； 动植生灵，皆为道侣。

「The interplay of ebb and flow in resonance with Heaven and Earth’s time and matter, silently embodied and verified, is unseen by the eye—this is the essence of *Yinfu* (阴符). Such is the principle of straightforward interpretation.

This passage illustrates the fundamental precepts of two traditions, each refining the essence of life and vitality through subtle yet profound mechanisms. The "foolish and fearful" approach to attaining sainthood refers to the female principle, as described in the *Zuozhuan* (《左传》): "Women are the *yang* (陽) of matter; their nature is singularly tranquil and focused." One must begin with the mind, thus harmonizing with the innate patterns of Heaven and Earth’s *wenli* (文理, cosmic order) to merge with the *true unity* (真一) born from the union of *qi* and emptiness, forming the *sacred embryo* (聖胎).

I, however, advocate the use of *wu xin* (無心, non-mindfulness), relying solely on the sufficiency of Heaven and Earth’s *wenli* and *qi* mechanisms. When the *qi* manifests in time, reaching ultimate emptiness and stillness, the *qi* naturally converges, and with true intent enveloping it, the *sacred embryo* is formed. For the *foolish* (愚, here referring to *Yin* or female principle) has no inherent mind; its *qi* is easily responsive. I, being inherently *zhong shi* (中實, complete and substantial), can only accept what is truly *void* (虚, empty). Such is the principle.

The core teaching of *Yinfu* reveals that the *foolish* (愚) and I each occupy our own realm, yet both possess *qi* mechanisms that transcend externally while never detaching from their own bodies. This creates a mystic interplay of presence and absence. The Three Realms (三才, Heaven, Earth, and Humanity) and the One Primordial (一元) fill the Six Directions (六合), and as we refine our practices, we each attain the realm of *voidness* (虚無). The Three Realms (三才) and Three Treasures (三宝), resting in *wu* (無, non-duality), meet in perfect harmony.

When *wu* (無) encounters *wu*, their union is seamless and undivided. Yet within this void, each contains *yin* and *yang*; in emptiness, they copulate and transform. To describe its marvels, one would exhaust the bamboo of the Southern Mountains—yet still not suffice. The deeper the void and stillness, the more vibrant the interplay of all transformations becomes, and the more abundant what is produced will be.

When one does not lose the proper timing, and in stillness receives the essence of matter, each gains their own fulfillment. The *foolish* and I, within this framework, each accumulate jade into mountains and spread gold across the earth. This is the foundation and manifestation of the earlier passage on "Heaven’s Killing Mechanism" (天发杀机).

The Sage unifies male and female, universally guiding all beings. Thus, there follows a further passage to elucidate distinct methods for transformation. Its essence is profound, yet its application is utterly simple and accessible. Yet few, past or present, have truly comprehended this text, for it was never transmitted through oral instruction.

Once one secretly grasps the master’s intent, the profound essence is revealed entirely—may those who see it strive together.

People attain sainthood through foolishness and fear, while I do so without them. People seek sainthood through the extraordinary, while I do without it.

To sink into the depths of water and fire is to court self-destruction.

Fan Zhi (范氏) says: "Foolishness" refers to one who does not discern, does not know, and remains muddled and unaware. This is the saying that one must act like the foolish. "Fear" means dreading that others might perceive my actions, and it also refers to explaining the *central palace* (中宫) through words. "Sainthood" is not aligned with ordinary paths, hence the phrase "attaining sainthood through foolishness and fear."

I, holding the universe within my grasp, see all transformations birthed from the body. The interplay of *Kan* (坎, water/yin) and *Li* (離, fire/yang), the union of *jin* (金, metal) and *mu* (木, wood), the emergence of the sacred function and divine clarity—all arise naturally from the Way of *wu wei* (無為, non-action). Thus, I attain sainthood without foolishness or fear. This is the hidden meaning behind the phrase "foolishness and fear" (愚虞).

Once one attains this understanding: Fan Zhi’s mistaken interpretations stem from treating the text as exclusively for men, clinging to the literal meaning of the characters, and failing to receive oral transmission. Relying solely on private reasoning, he further misconstrues the Primordial as merely *one* (一), exhausting his mind in vain and falling into erroneous paths.

It is better to follow the text’s straightforward meaning, and its significance will naturally become clear.

"Fear" (虞) is "degree" (度); "Sainthood" (聖) is "universal clarity" (通明). "Foolishness" (愚) means remaining fixed and tranquil like the foolish, though in truth, one is not foolish. "Extraordinary" (奇) refers to miraculous and divine applications. The Way of sainthood is natural, not extraordinary. Forcing extraordinary actions leads only to self-destruction.

The intent of this passage is to set the stage for the following discussion of "naturalness" (自然). Though it appears simple, its profundity is vast.

In the time of the Yellow Emperor (黃帝), the Way was spoken of without mention of *elixirs* (丹). Later ages introduced myriad explanations, yet they could be summarized by the two characters: *body* (身) and *mind* (心). According to this passage, it builds upon the previous one, presenting a fresh perspective—embracing the wonder of unity within multiplicity, and the grand Way of mutual completion.

Yet this is not achieved through artificial means. Hence, the following passage emphasizes the word "natural" (自然).

It states that one must enter through stillness (静), and that attaining the utmost stillness and emptiness to utilize extraordinary methods is the true practice. Even shattering the void into fragments is the ultimate goal.

The text still conceals its secrets, leaving them undivulged. The profound meaning of this passage must be unlocked through the oral transmission of Lu Zu (吕祖, Laozi’s immortal disciple).

If one says the previous passage spoke of the rules for entering, then within the cycles of day and night, large and small, there lies the application of divine clarity. This passage’ method, however, overturns all such applications—day and night, large and small, the patterns of time and matter, etc.

This is the art of encompassing the Three Realms (三才) as one, wearing lofty footwear and heavy robes, all as a single body. Moving and still, all living things are companions on the Way.

The innate nature encompasses the perfect whole like a suspended marble.

Yet, when the time comes to advance the fire or withdraw the talismans, one sits atop the marble’s apex to observe the fire’s readiness—this is the expansion of the *yīn-è* (鄞鄂) function. Once the fire’s readiness is complete, the body then penetrates into the marble, congealing and nourishing, thus resting the primordial spirit and also calming the *yīn-è*. At this moment, the ears and eyes perceive nothing, and the external form is foolish indeed—yet one does not know that great wisdom as foolishness is the path to sainthood. Heaven and earth undergo reversals, and the inner form is strange indeed—yet one does not know that harmonious interaction, not strangeness, is what makes one a sage.

For the previous passage’s method, it points to the true *qi* of the Three Realms dispersed as the expansion of my *yīn-è*—this is merely my true unity aiding, yet still unrelated to my primordial unity. This is but the Buddhist accumulation of relics in the body. The final passage’s extraordinary methods are the distinction of true unity, and their application is vast—all these are the ultimate principles of the Dao. If not aligned with the natural, one falls into peripheral doctrines. One sinks into fire and water.

The essence of the sacred scriptures is thus: The Dao of nature is still, so heaven and earth and all things are born. The Dao of heaven and earth is *jìn* (浸, permeating), so yin and yang prevail. Yin and yang interact, and transformation follows naturally.

Master Fan says: The Dao of nature being still is the primordial *Tàijí* in its pristine unity—stillness reaching its peak, then movement, generating heaven and earth as the grand ritual. The two forces interweave, then transform into all things—this reveals the natural cultivation of the primordial Dao in response to the times.

Yet the Dao of yin and yang, heaven and earth, is the ceaseless flow of *qi*, circulating and returning, gradually purifying until, at the appointed time, yin and yang prevail and interact. I then respond, filling and replenishing, making transformation smooth and ensuring all beings fulfill their nature—this reveals the phenomena of the postnatal *qi* conforming to the times. And conforming to heaven’s times is to know the moment when heaven and humanity act in unison—the time to move, the time to eat, the time of day and night’s waxing and waning—these are the roots of fire readiness.

One comment says: *Jìn* means mutual penetration and infusion. Yin within yang, yang within yin—thus, yin and yang prevail. Master Fan’s explanation here is deeply attuned to the Dao’s subtlety.

Yet one must know: when there is form, the function is equal to formlessness—reaching the point of utter formlessness while still appearing as if there were form. Upside-down, topsy-turvy—its profound meaning can be intuited but cannot be spoken. All is rooted in the utmost emptiness and profound stillness. Emptiness to its extreme means no obstruction, unhampered by postnatal influences, and able to refine with the Dao, returning to emptiness. Only then can one achieve stillness, and stillness brings clarity—when the moment arrives, one is aware, not confused, and actions are appropriate, avoiding the flaws of misaligned timing.

This is one moment, its mechanisms manifesting in primordial, postnatal, what should be welcomed, and what should be released. When it is time to advance, advance the fire; when it is time to withdraw, withdraw the talismans. Though natural, it must be guided by intent. And intent has its suppressions and elevations, its yielding and firmness, its slowness and haste, its penetration and concealment. From here, transformation arises, and saintly achievement emerges.

The late Master Tàixū Wēng said: “The sage transmits the medicine but not the fire, not because it is withheld, but because fire readiness arises with the times and acts according to the moment. Following a template like painting a gourd is impossible. The highest alchemical method is transmitted through the heart. The middle method must be orally instructed. The lowest method must be written down—its methods are cumbersome.

*The Yīnxú* scripture’s text is in cloud-like seals, spanning over ten feet, obtained by the Yellow Emperor from the *Kōngtóng* Celestial Altar. Even the Emperor’s wisdom relied on question-and-answer to clarify it. The versions revered today are those the Yellow Emperor personally inscribed, though written, their profound meaning lies in heart transmission. To rest in the essence of the text is to grasp its highest teaching.

Laozi further said: ‘Humans follow Earth, Earth follows Heaven, nothing follows the Dao, the Dao follows nature.’ The first sentence here, the Yellow Emperor has already revealed the essence. It shows that one must stand firm from before one’s parents were born, before heaven and earth existed, before creation left any trace. Knowing to align with nature is to return, drop by drop, to the source, and to merge, head by head, with the Dao.”

He also said: “The previous passage encompasses day and night’s waxing and waning, the patterns of time and matter—all things, sweeping them all away. Yet within this passage’s yin and yang transformations lies the meaning of knowing the times—this must be deeply understood. The intent of the previous passage warns against rigid adherence to forms; the intent of this text warns against neglecting the moment. My teacher, the *Níhuán* Master, said that what should be orally transmitted are precisely these profound truths.”

One comment notes: In this passage, the character “摧” (*cuī*, crush) in ancient and modern editions is uniformly written as “推” (*tuī*, push). Following the *Yìjīng*’s phrase “just and yielding push against each other,” this “摧” should indeed be “推.” The *Tàiwéi*律院’s hidden preceptor, with the national teacher and high scholar Wáng Kūnyáng, received transmitted artifacts. From the Chióu Ancestor onward, successive true persons passed down robes, bowls, scrolls, and as-you-will staves—among them, the *Kōngtóng Question-and-Answer*, bearing the Song Emperor Taizong’s imperial seal, titled as Chen Xīyí’s treasured edition, with Zhòngyáng Wángzǔ’s personally inscribed transmission precepts preserved. This is the ancient text from before the Song and Yuan dynasties, written with “摧.” Thus, this edition’s “摧” must have its source, not a scribal error.

Referring to the *Yìjīng*: “The dragon battles in the wild, its blood black and yellow”—the meaning of mutual crushing. One comment thus retains “摧” as in Master Fan’s text.

chunks.original_text: 上篇知之修之句，他本均作修炼，惟律院吕本作修之，文法较古。 盖范氏所得之本，必自律宗来者，故全经篇段节句悉从范本，不从他本分章标题，见者审之。 是故圣人知自然之道不可违，因而制之。 至静之道，律历所不能契。 爰有奇器，是生万物，八卦甲子，神机鬼藏，阴阳相胜之术，昭昭乎进乎象矣。 范氏曰：“自然之道，胎息三部之功也。 而胎息之功，非世俗所谓注意丹田，强拉河车之为。 乃先为天地之交，后行坎离之济，末运归中之妙。 是学在母腹之形状，使任督开通，升降流行，以资生化者。 莫不用十口之反文，得阳之下走，所以有“是故”之称也。 前之成圣登真，莫不由此，故立一无为不动之功，至当不易之法。 而此非律历之数计，可能契符。 于是，有奇器之用。 而此奇器实为道之源，气之本，万化之基，阴符之祖。 圣人藉之以为下手施功之地； 机于此器立而杀； 盗于此器而可而盗； 不神之神是于此器立可而获效； 周流八卦、甲子、水金，莫不由此器立可而逆旋； 天人合发，神迎鬼藏，莫不凭此器立可之功能也。 此器即阴阳相胜之术。 一进用之，必得口口刀圭之阳，故有昭昭之象。 而此器言于末章，是又示人用此奇器于末时也。 第此奇器，人以玄牝、炉鼎、丹田、太极等等指认，岂非正即《参同契》所称“圆三五，寸一分，口四八，两寸唇，长尺二，厚薄均”等句之谓，为奇器之形。 此中器字，有口对口，窍对窍之秘。 进字又用此奇器之处也。 功至用奇器未有不得其一而万事毕矣。 嗟乎，圣经当前，妙诀存心，造化现成，何甘自弃，而不知急务耶，勉之勉之。 一得曰：此解器字，与上下经文不贯，非正解也。 其引《参同契》，而曰奇器之形，中溺于注家邪说，更不可从。 惟云阳道人以河图洛书注圆三五等句，最为精确。 若以河图洛书注器字，庶乎近道矣。 形而上者谓之道，形而下者谓之器。 器者，道之象也。 按此“器”字，当作道字看，可作量字理会。 凡器有形质，而此器无形质； 凡器有大小，而此器无大小； 凡器有内外，而此器无内外； 凡器有尽藏，而此器无尽藏。 故曰：奇器。 以其范围天地，曲成万物，是以名之曰：“器”。 实天地之由生，方物之所从出也。 故曰：是生万物。 以其用言之，则曰器。 以其体言之，则曰道，自然之道也。 自然之道静，律历能测后天之动，而不能契先天之静。 八卦甲子，皆动中之数。 主宰乎八卦甲子之中者，此至静之奇器，有神机鬼藏之用存焉。 其在先天，无迹可名； 其在人身，则曰玄窍，亦无迹可见。 是物我同得于先天者，万物立命之基，即万物归根之地。 万化所由生，圣功所由作。 本此器以修身，则百骸理。 本此器以治人，则万化安。 圣人知天地有自然之道，制器不能契也。 爱有自然之奇器，是万物所由生者，因而本此器以制阴阳之有衍状，探本于生于万物之原，而后万化生乎身。 内则施之于一身，外则施之于天下，皆有神机鬼藏之妙用。 神者，阳气之伸，故言机。 鬼者，阴气之返，故言藏。 阴阳相胜，而适得其平，则万物生斯器，无象而昭昭有象矣，此观天道执天行之极功也。 范氏以私智诬大道，得吾说而存之，邪说庶几其息乎？

The preceding passage’s phrase *"knowing and cultivating"* is rendered as *"修之"* in the *Lǜyuàn* Lü edition alone—other versions read *"修炼"*—its syntax being more archaic. For the *Fàn* lineage’s text must derive from the *Lǜzōng* tradition, its entire structure—chapters, sections, and phrasing—conforms strictly to the *Fàn* edition, not the divided titles of other versions. Thus, the Sage knew the **Dao of Nature** could not be defied and accordingly regulated it.

The **Way of Supreme Stillness** transcends the reach of calendrical and astronomical measurements. There exists a wondrous **instrument**—the source of all things, the origin of **qi**, the foundation of ten thousand transformations, and the progenitor of the *Yīnfú*. The Sage employed it as the initial ground for practice; with it, one may **establish** and **slay**; with it, one may **plunder** and **steal**; the non-divine becomes divine through its use; the eight trigrams, *jiǎzǐ* cycles, and water-metal correspondences all reverse their motion through it; the confluence of heaven and humanity, the meeting of spirit and concealment—all depend on its function.

This **instrument** is the art of **yin-yang overcoming**. When applied, it inevitably yields the **mouth-mouth elixir-pill’s** solar essence, hence its manifest symbolism. Yet it is mentioned in the final chapter, indicating its use at the culmination of practice.

Men have identified this **instrument** as the *Xuāntāi*, the *Lúdǐng*, the *Dāntián*, or the *Tàijí*—is it not precisely the *"round three-five, inch-one-fen, mouth-four-eight, two-inch lips, length one-zhang-two, uniform thickness"* of the *Cāntóng Qìe*? Within it lies the secret of **mouth-to-mouth** and **orifice-to-orifice**. The term *"proceed"* (*jìn*) refers to its application.

When the practice reaches the stage of using this **instrument**, all else is complete. Alas! The sacred text lies before us, the marvelous key is in the mind, creation is already manifest—why would one willingly abandon it and neglect the urgent task? Exert yourself, exert yourself!

One who grasps this says: *"This interpretation of ‘instrument’ does not harmonize with the text above and below—it is not the correct exegesis. His citation of the *Cāntóng Qìe* to define its form betrays a misguided adherence to commentators’ heresies, and must be rejected. Only when the *Hétú-Luóshū* annotates the ‘round three-five’ passage does it attain precision. If the ‘instrument’ is annotated with the *Hétú-Luóshū*, then perhaps it approaches the **Dao**."*

That which transcends form is called **Dao**; that which is within form is called **instrument**. The **instrument** is the **Dao’s** manifestation. Examining the character *"instrument"* (*qì*), one should regard it as **"Dao"** or interpret it as **"measure"** (*liáng*). All **instruments** have tangible substance, yet this **instrument** lacks substance; all **instruments** have size, yet this one has none; all **instruments** have interior and exterior, yet this one transcends them; all **instruments** have limits, yet this one is boundless. Hence it is called *"wondrous **instrument**."* It encompasses heaven and earth, shapes all things—thus it is named **"instrument."** It is the means by which heaven and earth generate, the origin from which all things emerge. Hence it is said: *"It generates all things."*

When spoken of in terms of its function, it is called **"instrument."** When spoken of in terms of its essence, it is called **"Dao"**—the **Dao of Nature**. The **Dao of Nature** is still; calendrical and astronomical systems can measure the movements of **post-heaven**, but cannot fathom the stillness of **pre-heaven**. The eight trigrams and *jiǎzǐ* cycles are all numbers within motion. What governs the eight trigrams and *jiǎzǐ* is this **wondrous instrument of supreme stillness**, possessing divine subtlety and hidden efficacy.

In **pre-heaven**, it leaves no trace to name; in the human body, it is called the *Xuānqiào*—yet even this is invisible. This entity, shared by all beings in **pre-heaven**, is the foundation of their existence and the root to which they return. It is the source of all transformations, the origin of the Sage’s work. Cultivating the body through this **instrument** harmonizes the hundred bones; governing the world through it brings order to all things.

The Sage knew that heaven and earth possess the **Dao of Nature**, which no artificial **instrument** can replicate. Thus, he took this **wondrous instrument**—the origin of all things—as the foundation to regulate the patterns of **yin-yang**, probing the root of life’s emergence, so that all transformations arise within the body. Internally, it is applied to the self; externally, to the world—both yielding divine subtlety and hidden efficacy.

**"Divine"** refers to the extension of **yang-qi**, hence *"machine."* **"Ghostly"** refers to the return of **yin-qi**, hence *"concealment."* When **yin-yang overcoming** achieves balance, all things generate from this **instrument**, though it lacks form yet manifests symbolically—this is the ultimate function of observing the **Dao of Heaven** and embodying its operations.

*Fàn* relied on private speculation to distort the Great **Dao**; yet his words are preserved here. Perhaps heretical interpretations may now cease.
